title: CSV Injection at Camptix Event Ticketing

profile.name: Ian Dunn
profile.about: I'm a WordPress developer who maintains several small open source projects.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,
As you mentioned the scope of vulnerability as
>Any plugin listed on my WordPress.org profile. 
I am reporting this issue.

I have seen from your [WordPress.org](https://profiles.wordpress.org/iandunn/#content-plugins) profile the second plugin listed is **Camptix Event Ticketing**
So I looked at the source code of the plugin (https://github.com/Automattic/camptix)
Although I don't have much knowledge about wordpress plugin development what I understood that you have good filtering for XSS (html tags) when submitting user data (in ticket form)
But no filtering to filter out CSV macros (starts with `=`)
So I installed it in my WP and checked out it with a very simple ticketing with only *Firstname* ,*Lastname* and *Email*

**Reproduction of Bug**
1. From any open to buy ticket sign up for one.
2. In the *First name , Last name* field type `=AND(2>1)` and `=7*7` respectively.
3. Save them.
4. Now from admin panel export the attendees information as CSV. Open the CSV with any application (eg. Excel) and you'll see the First name and Last name field executes the command.
This can be further used to perform command execution on Windows system (high risk)
[See this](http://www.contextis.com/resources/blog/comma-separated-vulnerabilities/)
Since the bug could be exploited by random user and the victim is admin, I think it should be patched.

The **Fix** could be simple. Just escape `=` and `-` `+` signs from user input. this will solve the issue I guess.

Hope you resolve and reward.

------------------------------
Zawad
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,
As you mentioned the scope of vulnerability as

Any plugin listed on my WordPress.org profile.
I am reporting this issue.

I have seen from your WordPress.org profile the second plugin listed is Camptix Event Ticketing
So I looked at the source code of the plugin (https://github.com/Automattic/camptix)
Although I don't have much knowledge about wordpress plugin development what I understood that you have good filtering for XSS (html tags) when submitting user data (in ticket form)
But no filtering to filter out CSV macros (starts with =)
So I installed it in my WP and checked out it with a very simple ticketing with only Firstname ,Lastname and Email

Reproduction of Bug

  1. From any open to buy ticket sign up for one.
  2. In the First name , Last name field type =AND(2>1) and =7*7 respectively.
  3. Save them.
  4. Now from admin panel export the attendees information as CSV. Open the CSV with any application (eg. Excel) and you'll see the First name and Last name field executes the command. This can be further used to perform command execution on Windows system (high risk) See this Since the bug could be exploited by random user and the victim is admin, I think it should be patched.

The Fix could be simple. Just escape = and - + signs from user input. this will solve the issue I guess.

Hope you resolve and reward.

Zawad

activities.message:
Hi Zawad, thanks for the report! I've confirmed that this is valid.

I think the CVSS score is [8.3](https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H), and decided on $100 for the bounty. It's definitely a serious issue, because in the worst-case scenario, an attacker could completely compromise the user's device. It does rely on a lot of things outside the attacker's control, though:

* The user has to manually run the export tool.
* The CSV has to be opened in Excel. It sounds like the vulnerabilities that Context found in OpenOffice/LibreOffice are patched, and they don't allow arbitrary macros like Excel does. 
* The user has to ignore Excel's security warnings.

Let me know if I got any of that wrong, though.

I'm on vacation right now, but I'll be back on Monday and start working on a fix then. I'll let you know when there's a patch available to test.

xref https://hackerone.com/reports/72785
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Zawad, thanks for the report! I've confirmed that this is valid.

I think the CVSS score is 8.3, and decided on $100 for the bounty. It's definitely a serious issue, because in the worst-case scenario, an attacker could completely compromise the user's device. It does rely on a lot of things outside the attacker's control, though:

  • The user has to manually run the export tool.
  • The CSV has to be opened in Excel. It sounds like the vulnerabilities that Context found in OpenOffice/LibreOffice are patched, and they don't allow arbitrary macros like Excel does.
  • The user has to ignore Excel's security warnings.

Let me know if I got any of that wrong, though.

I'm on vacation right now, but I'll be back on Monday and start working on a fix then. I'll let you know when there's a patch available to test.

xref https://hackerone.com/reports/72785

activities.message:
Well, I expected the bounty to be around $200-$300 at least.
That would be good.
Although the victims needs to do some interaction but he is likely to do so because he (admin) downloaded the CSV from his own site.

HackerOne awarded more
Thanks.

activities.message:
The range I've published for high severity bounties is $100 - $400. My initial feeling was that this ranked towards the low end, because all of the complications I mentioned above significantly decrease the chances of a successful attack. 

It's not just that the admin had to run the exporter and open the file; the most significant complications are that they have to be running Excel, and that they have to choose to ignore the security warning that Excel displays.

I'll re-consider that and let you know what I decide, though.
activities.markdown_message:
The range I've published for high severity bounties is $100 - $400. My initial feeling was that this ranked towards the low end, because all of the complications I mentioned above significantly decrease the chances of a successful attack.

It's not just that the admin had to run the exporter and open the file; the most significant complications are that they have to be running Excel, and that they have to choose to ignore the security warning that Excel displays.

I'll re-consider that and let you know what I decide, though.

activities.message:
Hi Zawad, I've attached a patched version that I think fixes the vulnerability. Would you mind testing it and letting me know if you're able to exploit anything?

The new escaping function is `esc_csv()` on line 2858 of `camptix.php`.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Zawad, I've attached a patched version that I think fixes the vulnerability. Would you mind testing it and letting me know if you're able to exploit anything?

The new escaping function is esc_csv() on line 2858 of camptix.php.

activities.message:
Great! Thanks for testing it :)

It is expected that an Editor or Admin can cause XSS for **front-end visitors**. Even if the plugin blocked that for `[camptix]`, [WordPress itself would still allow it by entering HTML into regular posts/pages](https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/testing/reporting-security-vulnerabilities/#why-are-some-users-allowed-to-post-unfiltered-html).

If you can launch XSS **on a wp-admin screen**, though, that would be a valid vulnerability. #9391 was valid because the XSS happened inside wp-admin.

If you've something like found that, please submit a report for it. I'd love to get that fixed in the same release as the CSV vulnerability. You can use a single report for multiple instances of XSS.
activities.markdown_message:
Great! Thanks for testing it :)

It is expected that an Editor or Admin can cause XSS for front-end visitors. Even if the plugin blocked that for [camptix], WordPress itself would still allow it by entering HTML into regular posts/pages.

If you can launch XSS on a wp-admin screen, though, that would be a valid vulnerability. #9391 was valid because the XSS happened inside wp-admin.

If you've something like found that, please submit a report for it. I'd love to get that fixed in the same release as the CSV vulnerability. You can use a single report for multiple instances of XSS.

activities.message:
I need to coordinate this release with another team, so it looks like this issue and #152958 will be released in early August.

When that happens, you'll get public credit in the commit messages and changelog, and we can publish these reports.
